Algorithm5MC type I error rate1. For each replicate, indexed by j=1,,m(a) Generate the j-th random sample x(j)1,,x(j)n from the null distribution. (b) Compute the test statistic Tj from the j-th sample.(c) Record the test decision Ij=1 if H0 is rejected at significance level and otherwise Ij=0.2. Compute the proportion of significant tests 1
mIj. This proportion is the observed Type I error rate.

Algorithm9MH sampler1. Choose a proper proposal g(|Xt)2. Initialize X0 and repeat until the chain converges. At time t,(a) Generate Y from g(|Xt)(b) Compute the acceptance rate r(Xt,Y)=f(Y)g(Xt|Y)
f(Xt)g(Y|Xt)(c) Let (Xt, Y)=min{r(Xt,Y),1} be the acceptance ratio. Set Xt+1=a

Now we show how the MH sampler works.Let s, t be two different state. Without loss of generality, we assume that f(s)g(r|s)f(r)g(s|r). Then (r,s)=1 and (s,r)=f(r)g(s|r)
f(s)g(r|s), and a
P(Xt=s,Xt+1=r)=P(Xt=s)P(Xt+1=r|Xt=s)
=f(s)g(r|s)(s,r)
=f(r)g(s|r)
P(Xt=r,Xt+1=s)=P(Xt=r)P(Xt+1=s|Xt=r)
=f(r)g(s|r)(r,s)
=f(r)g(s|r)
 P(Xt=s,Xt+1=r)=P(Xt=r,Xt+1=s)Thus a
P(Xt=r)= sP(Xt=r,Xt+1=s)
= sP(Xt=s,Xt+1=r)
=P(Xt+1=r)
The Markov chain is stationary at f.We can also prove it in a kernel point of view. Define K(r,s)=g(s|r)(r,s) be the transition kernel from r to s. We call f is the stationary distriibution if the balance condition holds f(r)K(r,s)dr=f(s)Under MH sampler, a
f(r)K(r,s)=f(r)g(s|r)(r,s)
=f(r)g(s|r)min{1,f(s)g(r|s)
f(r)g(s|r)}
=min{f(r)g(s|r), f(s)g(r|s)}
=f(s)g(r|s)(s,r)
=f(s)K(s,r)
We have the detailed balanced consition f(r)K(r,s)=f(s)K(s,r). Then f(r)K(r,s)dr=f(s)K(s,r)dr=f(s)K(s,r)dr=f(s)6.2.2. Metropolis samplerWith symmetric proposal g(X|Y)=g(Y|X). r(Xt, Y)=f(Y)

Define evidence lower bound (ELBO) as ELBO(q)Eq{logf(x,z)}-Eq{logq(z)}Then logf(x)=KL(q(z)||p(z|x))=KL(q(z) || p(x|z))+ELBO(q)ELBO(q)To minimize KL(q(z) || p(x|z)), we maximize ELBO(q).a

To maximize ELBO(q), on one hand, we maximize Eq{logf(x|z)}, i.e., find q that fits the data. On the other hand, we minimize KL(q(z)||(z)), i.e., find q that fits the prior.8.3.
